BE11:17am

This announcement follows recent press speculation that Persimmon’s ability to take part in the Help to Buy scheme was under jeopardy because of sub-standard housing which it provides customers. Indeed, Persimmon has consistently scored a 3-star rating (out of 5) in the House Builders Federation customer satisfaction survey. This announcement will be welcomed by the market as Persimmon looks to secure its position within the Help to Buy scheme which represents over 55% of its annual completions. With the stock offering a

10% yield we remain positive on the stock despite the macro uncertainty and recent question marks regarding build quality.

DJ morning everyone
Tony Scott @TH- Im sure they were more concerned in the short term about the lack of affordable housing that was all over the papers at the time. Im sure they didnt expect the houses to be sub standard within such a short space of time of HtB coming into play
BE11:18am

Sorry, that was Goodbody not Shore.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

And this is Shore not Goodbody.

Viking1 Good old Levi’s 10x oversubscribed ?
BE11:18am

This is a recognition of a major problem for this industry and Persimmon in particular and there is growing pressure from buyers and the government for a large increase in the quality of new homes.

The danger for Persimmon is, we believe that, that this will allow a far greater number of buyers to come forwards and demand that their new home is put right and this is likely to have an impact on margins. Additional costs will need to be incurred post-sale (this would likely to be the case in the early days of the scheme) but longer term more money will need to be spent on core construction and inspection costs. We do not feel that Persimmon is likely to generate any additional sales through this exercise and it is likely to be a net cost. Buyers today, especially in Persimmon’s case, are largely blinded by their desire to access the significant financial benefits available through Help to Buy (close to 60% of Persimmon’s open market sales use this pivotal government incentive) – we believe that buyers have been buying almost regardless of product and service quality. For a buyer with only a 5% deposit, using help to buy lowers monthly mortgage payments by close to 40% at current interest rates – at Persimmon’s average selling price that would save a buyer almost £22,000 in lowered mortgage payments over the five year interest-free period of help to buy.

On the point of help to buy, it has been mooted (based on apparent comments by the Housing Minister) that Persimmon could be excluded from the scheme after 2021 and while this was not taken especially seriously by the market, this action might suggest that Persimmon has been shown some form of yellow card or have had a wake-up of some sort. Without help to buy, we firmly believe Persimmon would sell fewer houses and report materially lower margins.

Will this set a precedent? Probably not. Persimmon has been lagging behind it peers for some time and did need to do something to catch up. It does risk more generally emboldening buyers to complain and demand that faults are corrected. We believe that the new homes industry has been pushing the envelope (down) on product quality and specification largely because of help to buy and buyers have been prepared to accept a less than perfect product in a way they would simply not accept for a new car or new consumer goods. This has, we believe, been a key factor in the strength of the industry’s margins in the last 3-4 years and some of that benefit is likely to wind back. Taken together with a visibly weakening pricing environment we still believe that house builders’ margins have peaked, that industry commentary on prospects remains too bullish and consensus forecasts (that generally predict rising profits through to 2021) are too high.

Persimmon has slipped back through March having followed the sector rally and rose 30% from the pre-Christmas low of 1885p. Since then the shares have been marked xd of 125p of special dividend and battered by concerns about help to buy. The shares have slipped back below our fair value (2295p) and while this news today might provide a small fillip we would still be looking to top slice here and across the sector after the spectacular rebound through Q1 of CY2019. We keep our recommendation at BUY for now but the conviction we had back in December has now all but run out.

Q3 19 (Dec 18 – Feb 19) is the second quarter where the ESMA regulations have been in effect for the whole period. Market conditions in February were
particularly unfavourable for client trading (low volatility, weak trending).
Revenues were 8.5% weaker than we expected. Active OTC leveraged customers numbers in the ESMA region were 3% higher than we expected, offset by
lower active clients in EMEA ex-EU and APAC; total OTC active customers were in line with our estimates. ESMA Retail customers were 1.5% higher than
they were in Q2 18, and 3.6% higher than our estimate, which we view as positive (although we would caution against placing too much emphasis on a single
quarter).
We continue to view the shares as undervalued, and affirm our Outperform rating, but note our Speculative Risk qualifier. Market conditions are always difficult to
forecast (customers prefer upward trending markets, with moderate volatility) and, at the new lower levels of leverage (which makes trading less “exciting”, all
else equal), the trading activity of ESMA Retail customers in any given period, is currently more challenging to project.
However, we believe IG has the ability to adapt to the changed regulatory environment, with plans to launch an exchange-traded offering for the Continental
European market in May 2019, and having already launched (January) a US retail FX offering in the US.

A weak quarter, another downgrade, but ESMA impact looks limited:Q3 revenue was£108m, -12% vs Q2 19, and -29% vs Q3 18, albeit thiswas the peak of the cryptocurrencybubble, accounting for 11% of Q3 18 revenue.We have now downgraded forecasts ineach of the last three IG statements, this time with EPS -9%. Whilst this is frustrating given our OW rating, the statement is clear that weakness was driven by lower revenue per client (ie ‘dull’markets, especially in February) rather than ESMA regulation or client attrition. Whilst we expect a negative share price reaction given anEPSdowngrade, we believe that:i) many investors were expecting a poor statement,given commentary from peers, ii) ESMA Retail revenue was only -4% vs Q2, whereas ESMA professionalrevenue was -20% vs Q2, adding credibility to the viewthat weaknessis simply market driven, and iii) ESMA Professional clients were unchanged vs Q2, with ESMA Retail clients actually growing 2%. This isencouraginggiven that active client numbersoften fallin dull quarters. Finally, we note Q3 revenues are down 8%on a 2-year basis, albeit Q317 was described as a quiet quarter.

BE11:27am

EPS cut 9% in FY19, PT to 780pin line with downgrade: Our new FY19 EPS of 42.2p assumes a ‘normal’ quarter in Q4from a volatilityperspective, with revenueof £122m, in line with Q219. Cost guidance is unchanged, and we leave FY20/21 EPS unchanged. This may appear optimistic, but our rationale is that the weak Q3 is not ESMA driven, and we await the ‘business and strategic update’ on 22ndMay for more clarity on revenue potential from innovation (eg US Forex, MTF). The dividend is being retainedat 43.2p “until the Group’s earnings allow the Company to resume progressive dividends”. Withan 8% yield, we believe the market is pricing ina potential cut, unsurprising given a c102% payout ratio in FY19. We forecast the payout ratio drops to 88% in FY20, and this will be critical in determining whether IG is a deep value share orover-distributing

Tencent recorded a sharp drop in profits and a deceleration in sales growth in the last quarter as the Chinese tech company was buffeted by a moratorium on new game approvals and intensifying competition from younger tech start-ups.

Tencent, China’s second most valuable company behind rival Alibaba, said profit attributable to shareholders was down 32 per cent year on year in the fourth quarter at Rmb14.23bn ($2.13bn).

Revenues rose 28 per cent to Rmb84.9bn, ahead of analysts’ estimates of Rmb83.37bn, according to Bloomberg, but half the level of growth a year ago.

BE11:46am

PBT of £723m, as expected
FY19 PBT was in line with guidance at £723m. The dividend was in line with UBSe at 165p. Within the mix, Retail was a shade better than UBSe on a better H2 cost performance. Online was a shade lower with less cost leverage. Next Finance profit was also slightly lower, although the H1 rise in bad debts has subsided. YE net debt was £1,096m vs UBSe £1,158m, with slightly lower than UBSe growth in the debtor book. Guidance unchanged, Label and International shine, bad debt lower
FY20 PBT guidance remains at £715m. Retail EBIT margin is expected to compress by 350bp (FY19 170bp), in part likely from lower markdown benefit as well as higher gearing on a lower base margin. Retail sales are expected to decline 8.5%. Online margin is expected to hold steady at c18.5% on sales up 11%. Dilution from Label should be offset by lower print costs. Label and Overseas are growing strongly. FY20 combined sales guidance is £930m, 24% of Next Brand product sales, and 20% up on FY19. Bad debt guidance is for a decline from 4.5% to 4.2% as the impact of historical internal credit decisions washes out.
UBS estimates unchanged, lower bad debts
UBS FY20E PBT remains at £725m, slightly higher than guidance as we expect some share gains from capacity reduction in the mid market. The key issue is whether Next can grow profit over the medium term. Although the costs of channel shift seem to have fallen (6p in the £ in FY19 from 13p in FY18, partly from better rents), there is still a headwind. We think that industry capacity reduction plus the change in the mix of Next's sales base (more Label and Overseas) will allow some medium-term growth, which can be geared up by buybacks. This is even after possible reinvestment of scale gains in lower Label commission rates.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Next has produced a perfectly acceptable set of results, and an
outlook statement that suggests that it continues to manage a
difficult channel shift dynamic as well as could be expected.
There are no changes to numbers this morning. The Prelims
announcement is read with interest by all and sundry as it also
gives the company’s view on the consumer for the year ahead
and it is relatively upbeat. In Next’s eyes the consumer has no
need nor inclination to retrench, and it does not see political
uncertainty affecting consumer behaviour. So, the sector readacross
is positive. We continue to believe that the market has a
pretty good handle on Next’s prospects and we cannot got
excited about the shares. The sector make take it well though.

Forester @shinshin Rowan Atkinson gramophone sketch come to mind!
Tom Dalgleish Often CFD's are the best or only way of getting on a foreign stock
BE11:47am

Next’s remarks on the consumer are always well-thumbed and this year it is relatively upbeat. In the context of non-disastrous Brexit, Next thinks that its customers are in better shape than they were last year, with real wage growth and full employment. It sees no reason for the consumer to retrench and has not seen any evidence that the shopper reacts to political uncertainty. This is largely how we see the sector, and there must be a degree of pent up demand given other externalities that have have had an impact on the retailers (mostly the weather).

Forester @BC well i am not invested, but Next has pretty damn good management for starters!
red CFDs are only short term. financing costs eat gains if held for more than a few days.
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian So, wise ones, where are we supposed to invest to see our pensions rise over the next decade? Picture tumbleweed blowing everywhere.
BE11:48am

Next is very good at outlining its strategy and its prospects (which in some respects is why the shares are always so range-bound). This time it is focussing on how it sees life from a channel perspective and the issues that this brings. Each £1 of sales that shifts from retail to online “costs” the company 6p. This margin structure is not unusual but it outlines how it does face a future of pushing water uphill given it sees retail sales down 8% this year. At least, however, Next knows where the hill is, and statements like these demonstrate its pragmatic approach to its lot. Rent remains an area in which Next can make material cost savings, which will make interesting reading for other retailers and property companies.

TH11:49am

The shift online is not quite as one-way as it might first appear. It costs us less to deliver Online orders to our stores than to a customer’s home. So, we offer free delivery for orders collected in store, as against a charge of £3.99 for delivery to home. For many customers the store collection service is not only cheaper, it is also more convenient than staying at home to receive a delivery. As a result, around half of our Online orders are delivered to our stores. These orders, though smaller in value than orders
delivered to home, represent one third of our Online turnover.
Shops are even more important in facilitating Online returns. Over 80% of all our Online returns come back through our stores. So, for the moment, our Retail estate and staff remain central to the service we offer Online. The development of our stores as part of our Online Platform will remain a critical part of our stores work-programme for the year ahead.

of billions of dollars.
BAT, Philip Morris International Inc. and a local unit of
Japan Tobacco Inc. are defendants in lawsuits by Canada’s 10
provinces that want to recoup health-care costs linked to the
effects of smoking, a move reminiscent of the U.S. in the 1990s.

decades, is scheduled to come to trial this year.

from BAT report: A contributing factor to the decline
of legal tobacco volumes is the rise in the consumption of illicit products.
Cigarettes are a reliable source of tax revenue for governments worldwide, and price differentials between markets, regulatory changes and broader macroeconomic pressures have driven the establishment of a significant illicit cigarette trade. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that
one in every ten cigarettes and tobacco products consumed globally is illicit, with the market supported by various players, ranging from individuals to organised criminal networks involved in arms and
human trafficking.
It is generally accepted that there is a direct correlation between steep and ad hoc increases in taxes and an increase in illicit sales, with the current sanctions doing little to deter criminals for whom profits from the
illegal sale of tobacco remain an appealing prospect. For example, following successive excise increases, the Australasia region has
seen legal volumes decline substantially. However, in markets where effective action has reduced the prevalence of illegal tobacco,
legal volumes have been restored.

BE12:15pm

In 2012, Merlin acquired Living and Leisure Australia, which included a number of
aquariums in Asia-Pacific. One of those was Changfeng Ocean World in Shanghai, which
included a stadium-based show featuring two Beluga Whales. Since then, management has
been working on multi-year project, culminating in plans to transfer these whales to a
Merlin-funded sanctuary off the coast of Iceland in April this year.
In our view, management should be commended for its tenacity in seeing that multi-year
project through, given that most would probably consider it absolutely “the right thing to
do”; however, it is worth noting that the financial impact will be noticeable for the Midway
division in 2019, and investors should be forewarned in terms of our estimates.
According to management, Changfeng Ocean World has been one of the top 10 performers
in the Midway division, and as many as half of visitors came specifically to see the whale
shows. As a result, it expects revenue at that site to roughly halve in the near term – and
while plans are in place to replace the stadium with a new attraction, the company does not
expect to fully recover the lost revenue. If we (crudely) assume that Changfeng Ocean
World represents c2% of Midway revenue, that would imply that if revenue does halve as
management expects, the site could create a c1ppt drag on Midway’s lfl growth in 2019.
